Narva mnt 18
51009 Tartu linn, 
Tartu linn, Tartumaa 
EST

description.en: The following models are discussed: risk-free market model, scenario based models with discrete time, binomial models and Black-Scholes models.
description.et: Vaadeldakse riskivabasid ning stsenaariumidel põhinevaid diskreetse ajaga mudeleid, binomiaalmudeleid ja Black-Scholesi mudeleid.

objectives.en: The goal of the course is consider fundamental mathematical models of financial markets and derivatives.
objectives.et: Tutvuda põhiliste finantsturu ja tuletisväärtpaberite matemaatiliste mudelitega.

learning_outcomes.en: After passing this course the student:
1. is familiar with  the main mathematical models of the financial markets;
2. knows how to find the prices of the bonds and the derivativest;
learning_outcomes.et: 2) oskavad leida derivatiivide ja võlakirjade hindu

learning_outcomes.en: 3. is familiar with the binomial model and knows how to find the prices of the European and American options
learning_outcomes.et: 3) oskavad kasutada binommmudelit põhiliste optsioonide hinna leidmiseks

independent_work.et:
1. homework - constructing the arbitrage-free model using data of the real bond market
2. homework - find the prices of the European and American options using binomial and trinomial model.
3. homework - constructing different portfolios   according to the Markowitz portfolio theory

description.et:
Test - the theory and exercises about the risk-free market model. Feedback
in terms of points obtained will be provided in the study information system
during 7 days after test.

First homework about the finding price of the bond (using Excel). Feedback
in terms of points obtained will be provided in the study information system. If
more detailed (personal) feedback is wanted, students should contact the
lecturer.

Second homework about the binomial model. Feedback in terms of points
obtained will be provided in the study information system. If more detailed
(personal) feedback is wanted, students should contact the lecturer

Third homework about the Markowitz portfolio theory. Feedback in terms of points
obtained will be provided in the study information system. If more detailed
(personal) feedback is wanted, students should contact the lecturer

Final exam (theory and exercises). To pass exam you have to get at least 20 points. Feedback will contain the score obtained, provided
via study information system in 7 days after the second exam date.

grade_preconditions.et: To qualify for a final examination it is necessary to get at least 10.5 points (max 20) for the test and at least 15 points for the home works (max 30).

assessment_scale.et: Eristav (A, B, C, D, E, F, mi)
assessment_scale.en: differentiated (A, B, C, D, E, F, not present)

description.et:
Basic Financial Mathematics. Risk-free and risky securities. Bonds. Yield of bond.
 Operationally perfect market. The Law of One Price. Arbitrage
Risk free market model. The portfolio of assets . The arbitrage free model. Attainable future cash flows. Discount factors
First and second main theorems  for the risk free model
Attainable future cash flows. Discount factors.
Estimating the price of unattainable future cash flows. Yield of the bond
Estimating the price of unattainable future cash flows.
Using the data of the real market to compose the model of the real market.

Using the data of the real market to compose the model of the
real market I.
Forward- and swap-rates.

Using the data of the real market to compose the model of the
real market II. Forward- and swap-rates.

Scenario based finite model: elements of the model, describing the information
structure of the model. Trading strategies and portfolios of assets
Test

Attainable future cash flows and replicating portfolios for European and American options.
Arbitrage and self-financing portfolios.
Information structure of the model. Price, value and cash flow related with portfolio. Attainable future cash flow
The risk-neutral probability measure.
The risk-neutral probability measure I.
The existence and the uniqueness of the risk-neutral probability measure
Estimating the price of unattainable future cash flows. State prices, stochastic discount factors
The Binomial model.
The risk-neutral probability measure. Estimating the price of unattainable future cash flows.
The price of the European call- and put-option
The Binomial model I.

The behavior of the rate of return and the price of the underlying asset, if number of the
periods goes to infinity.
The Binomial model II.
The limit price of European option. Replicating portfolio
Modern Portfolio Theory I. Mean-Variance Analysis of Risk and Return.
Modern Portfolio Theory II
Modern Portfolio Theory I.

Continuous time market model (Black-Scholes model). Modelling the rate of return and
the price of the risky asset
Modern Portfolio Theory II
Continuous time market model. The existence of the martingale probabilities.
Continuous time market model. The price of the European option.
